block.p: Ford Releases Data on Tires That Firestone Recalled Ford Motor released documents showing that Bridgestone/Firestone had received for years an unusually large number of claims on the tires that were recalled last week.

The highest numbers of claims by a wide margin were for tires produced at Bridgestone's factory in Decatur, Ill., in 1994 and 1995, when the factory was operated by replacement workers. Until now, Ford and Firestone sought to present a united front. But several disclosures indicate that their relationship is being strained by the tire recall. [Page A1.]

Venture to Offer Video-on-Demand Intertainer and Akamai Technologies plan to announce a partnership today to deliver video-on-demand to the computers of consumers with high-speed Internet connections. The service, which is now available in Cincinnati and Denver, will be broadly available by the end of the year, the companies said. [C5.]

Jobs Finds Fault With New Book ''The Second Coming of Steve Jobs,'' a book by Alan Deutschman, portrays Steven P. Jobs, the co-founder and chief executive of Apple Compute, as an abusive, insecure narcissist who, through a ''reign of terror,'' turned around the company and reclaimed his authority. Last week, Mr. Jobs called the chief executive of Random House, the publisher's parent, to complain about the book, referring to it as a ''hatchet job.'' [C9.]

NBC Joins the Reality Show Fray After a long delay, NBC will announce this week that it has acquired the rights to ''Chains of Love,'' a reality show that will chain four men to one woman for a week. NBC has also acquired the rights to a hidden-camera show called ''Sweet Revenge,'' in which a contestant will be offered a chance to get back at a friend or family member by setting him or her up for embarrassment on a hidden camera. [C9.]

A Space Detour for Web Traffic Delivering simultaneous streams of music to thousands or even millions of listeners over an ever more clogged Internet has become increasingly frustrating. If the audio stream hits too many traffic jams, listeners may find radio programs stuttering or stopping in the middle of a song. One promising remedy involves sending the stream up to a satellite and landing it at a network hub closer to listeners. [C4.]

Networks' Convention Role Shrinks The three main broadcast networks are likely to continue to play a role at political conventions, and the parties are likely to continue to covet every moment on these high-visibility networks. But the scaling back in prime time that occurred this year is expected to only intensify the next time. Media. [C9.]

Japan Heads to Web Without Wires While Internet access through high-speed lines is booming in the United States, the business in Japan is barely sputtering. The Japanese are heading onto the Internet in droves -- but by wireless means. There are at 20 million to 27 million Internet users in Japan, or one of every five people in the nation. Of that number, nearly half are connecting to the Internet wirelessly. New Economy. [C4.]

Web Entrepreneurs Stepping Aside Anecdotal evidence suggests that a changing of the guard is under way in the Internet industry, as the early proponents of the Web are stepping aside for the mainstream business people who have migrated to the new medium. Analysts say the executive shift could have broad implications for e-commerce.Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C7.]

Hyundai Founder to Sell Auto Stake Hyundai Group, South Korea's largest business group, said that its founder would sell a 6.1 percent stake in Hyundai Motor by the end of the year, ending months of defiance of government demands for reorganization. [C2.]
